author: shawman123
body: There is no question that Qualcomm will be around 10+ years. They have moats in many segments and are now making AR/VR chips which are going to be huge. There will be negative catalysts like Apple making its own modem(still have to pay licensing to QCOM for using 3g/4g if I am not wrong). Exynos with AMD GFX might at one point end up better than QCOM chips and low/medium end soc's are in competition against Mediatek. Still they should be around for a long time.

author: hermeticstudy
body: The bear case is relatively short runway for growth that is derisked. Yes, they are the unquestioned leader in 5G modem and RF technology currently, and will benefit from a historic refresh cycle as all handsets become 5G-enabled (this is already underway). However, beyond that, handset units isn't a viable growth story (penetration already high) - so Qualcomm will have to depend on design wins in auto, notebook PCs etc, where their dominance is far from a sure thing. Others have already noted the potential for in-sourcing of iPhone components that could disrupt the handset moat over time.

author: miscsubs
body:
To counter your counter, it seems Apple hired a lot of Intel modem engineers who came up with an inferior product despite Intel’s expertise in semiconductors.

Making modems is hard, very hard. I seriously doubt Apple (or anyone) can come from behind and catch up to QCOM.

There is a reason QCOM wasn’t scared to go to (legal) war with Apple over this and was one of few companies that bent Apple’s will.

IMO, the biggest bear case for QCOM is/was regulatory due to their aggressive licensing practices. But they won that battle too, surprising many of us who thought otherwise.

Maybe if 5G flops or has very slow adoption, then there is another concern but I don’t know if I’d bank on that.

author: GYN-k4H-Q3z-75B
body: The split is nice and Nvidia is doing well, but my eyes are still on the ARM merger. If that gets the nod from regulators, Nvidia is golden. If it does not, growth becomes harder for Nvidia. The reason is that ARM as an architecture stands to expand into the desktop segment. Apple is transitioning, and Windows has the software support but is lacking the hardware. The merger would give Nvidia control over the architecture and companies like Apple and Qualcomm would have to pay royalties to Nvidia who could at the same time churn out their own ARM chips.

author: ScipioAfricanvs
body: I’ve just started looking into QCOM as well as it would be directly relevant to me (RSUs if I accept a job there). I personally think they are well positioned and we’ve recently seen how important some of their technologies are. Apart from Apple, which others have mentioned, one potential weakness is China - if there’s ever a trade war, tariffs, sanctions, etc. their revenue would take a huge hit.

author: NPPraxis
body:
This is my exact argument. Apple has proven that they can easily crush Qualcomm’s designs and that ARM is viable for laptops.  Pretty quickly everyone is going to make their own ARM chips if Qualcomm can’t dramatically increase performance.

Apple is also working on their own 5G modem and there are potential monopoly legal issues with some of their behavior.

author: Flakmaster92
body:
Chip shortage for one. But also everyone is getting into making their own chips. 

Apple makes their own with the A/M/W series, Amazon makes their own ARM cores (if you don’t think they’ll bring them to kindle and Alexa devices eventually, you’re crazy). Microsoft is rumored to be working on their own, possibly for Azure, possibly for future Surface products. Samsung has their own with Exynos. Google is rumored to be unveiling a new Pixel phone with their own SoC. 

Qualcomm still has patents and modem tech, that’s true and fair however all of the above players will eat onto their SoC profits. They’ll exist, but I wouldn’t be banking on same levels of growth moving into the future.

Before a single new chip is made with this investment, it is the capital equipment manufacturers that will benefit FIRST.  

ASML, AMAT, KLAC, KLIC, LRCX

This will not help NVDA, QCOM, or AMD until new fab capacity is online (so end of 2022 at the earliest).  Once more fab capacity has been created, the chip designers should benefit from lower contract manufacturing prices.

author: WalterBoudreaux
body:
>Sounds like it could be compelling and is there B/S in good shape?

Yes, balance sheet is pristine. If you re-read my original post, I mention how post-IPO, they had $300 million in cash and no debt.

>I pause becuz Vizio doesn’t make their own TV components and will always have an inferior product.

Pretty sure neither do a lot of the "big name" brands. Everyone buys TV OLED panels off of LG. Sony can't even put more than 2 HDMI 2.1 ports even in their top $4,000 OLED TV right now because they are having to buy the chip off of MediaTek. Just 2 quick examples.

>Personally I stay away from their TVs and over last 15 years go with LG (recently with Samsung, which was disappointing). 

LG's non-OLED TVs are complete trash. They are THE market leader in OLED though and make all the OLED panels (Sony and Vizio buy OLED panels from LG). Sony overall makes the best non-OLED TVs. Basically if you want the best high end, get an LG OLED or debatably a Sony OLED, which uses an LG OLED panel but Sony's own processor.

Samsung has been churning out trash TVs for a few years now (because they know most people are too clueless to realize it and will fork over $ for Samsung brand). The exception is the top few models, all of which are really overpriced in my view vs. Sony.

>Are these profit margin numbers indicative of Vizio’s industry in whole, or is Vizio ascending to a leading position? 

Vizio's platform gross margins are a lot higher than Roku's. I'm not sure why yet.

>Curious as I’d expect every smart TV to have an ad selling platform.

Almost none of the others fully control theirs. Sony licenses Google/Android TV OS. Samsung uses some Linux-based one called Tizen. LG licenses webOS from QualComm. TCL licenses Roku. Hisense licenses both Roku and Android. The final piece here is that ad selling platforms don't move the needle for massive conglomerates like Samsung and LG. Not to mention that these platforms are not mutually exclusive....will advertisers only want to reach Roku customers and just ignore the millions who own Vizio's for example? No. They want to get the furthest reach possible!

Let me know if you have any other q's

author: littlered1984
body: Different perspective - in my experience QCOM can struggle to recruit top engineers as they are not FAANG(not MS/AMD/NVDA either), which can be an issue when it comes to company growth. When I was interviewing for jobs about 5 years ago, I had offers from a number of places including QCOM. QCOM ranked towards the bottom in interesting projects and clearly wasn't a leader in the space I work. "A great perk is that we get offices instead of cubicles, plus  we get to be in sunny San Diego vs the bay area" is the main selling point I heard from nearly everyone there I talked to. San Diego is a risk as other top companies aren't there - you can't change jobs easily. And offices vs cubicles was a weird one in retrospect as many people work from home these days.

author: third_legatron
body:
Be careful. That guy just told you to buy stocks that have been on a losing spree for a bit. This isn't the market cycle for frothy tech stocks. I'm a fan of semiconductor plays like , QCOM, Lam research, AMD and intel (long hold, short is hairy.) I like big tech with good earnings and decently low peg and pe multiples. Tech is presenting some good buying opportunities, but the market is rampant with companies that just simply won't make it. Stick to blues chip names that have gotten beaten up and dca into a solid position. Anything else speculative, may be comparable to catching a falling knife.

Apph isn't terrible and has promise. 

EV is solid, but very expensive for most investments right now, as most don't turn a profit. Tesla barely even turns a profit and is the first mover. To play this space, I would go with legacy automakers like Gm or ford or volkswagen, as they are on a path to integrate EVs into their lineups. 

Other than automakers, I would buy lithium miners like Livent or albemarle. Precious metals like palladium and rhodium related stocks may also be good buys because PGM metals are used in EV cars as well as ICE cars. 

Right now, industrials are good, although with the inflation narrative, stocks with pricing power are in demand. Healthcare, tobacco, oil (eh, I'm bullish, but I'm biased), food and beverage (pepsi, Coca-Cola, etc) will probably do decent under this volatility, but won't make you heaps of money either. 

Banks are also decent buys, I like Citi and BAC. They will do well under inflation BUT have already went on a bit of a tear so dca into a position may be smart.

author: bernie638
body:
My condolences. 

Unfortunately,  good advice gets down voted to invisible and ridiculed around here.

Having a diversified portfolio helps a lot,  my biggest loser from 2013 has been my biggest winner this year (TROX).  Unfortunately I left it for dead and didn't reballance into it. If you don't want to spend a lot of effort finding good companies in different areas and periodically reballancing,  just by a low cost index fund and they do it for you. 

Another way is to dump your losers and let your winners run.  Ignore the price you paid for the stock,  that's the most meaningless thing and it would benefit humanity if that number was hard to find.   The important thing, is it going to go up from the price today? People sell something that still has a lot of upside just because they are up some arbitrary amount or hold something going down because they don't want to "sell for a loss " and instead take an even bigger loss.  Again,  if you're holding a diversified portfolio then you would sometimes sell a portion of your winners and buy your low priced losers to keep roughly the same dollar amount in each sector. Example,  I sold 2/3 of QCOM after it shot up big in February and put that money into beaten down energy and materials.  I  didn't get rid of all my QCOM,  but it was back to 1/15th of my total dollar amount.

author: loin-king
body: AMD 7nm gave them a perf and power advantage wrt intel in data centers. Not all applications are arm friendly… but I understand that is changing (may take 5-10 years). Apple definitely can make strides with ARM as they have a strong hardware team. Google/Amazon/Microsoft, in my view do not have the hardware focus and do not have the talent to cut AMD in data center… we will know in 3-5 years. I doubt apple will share their Soc or design with other tech companies and they currently do not have cloud offering… google/Amazon can go to qcom but qcom is mostly strong on modem side… I doubt nvidia can close the ARM deal, but if they are successful, it will again cause a disruption and vendors would try to look elsewhere… I guess Nvidia would try to close the ecosystem and slow down the innovation in ARM. The bigger shift in DC is with TPUs and ML specific processors… nvidia would be hurt once everyone comes out with ML specific cores… I assume intel and AMD are trying something there. Google has the lead and Amazon maybe trying to copy things. Microsoft will most likely try to buy qcom/AMD/ml-hardware company… I doubt they can come up with a cpu internally. Interesting times ahead.

author: Additional-Primary-8
body: https://twitter.com/Qualcomm/status/1398338359446151171?s=20

author: introvertedhedgehog
body:
Looking at Nokia, Ericsson and Huawei on the radio side gives a hint as to what the competitive situation could become where basically incombants are challenged by a low cost option (in this example Huawei) that is also very technically competitive.

That said currently Qualcomm is very dominant..I think non technical people overstate the potential there competition has in the short term. Like they forget Qualcomm has had years and years working in the standards bodies steering the direction of LTE and 5G to be to its liking and not faced the competition Ericsson for example has always faced from Nokia. Qualcomm is deeply entrenched.

And you should remember that it's a US company. The US banned Huawei and there is not a top US radio vendor benefitting from that the way Ericsson Nokia and Samsung do. The US will go far to protect Qualcomm from competition from outside the US. The security concerns are similar as on the radio side.

Bearish ideas:

*It's not sexy to regular consumers. Maybe the valuation is just 'good' and the rest of the market is crazy right now with TLSA, AAPL and Bitcoin making everything consumer facing crazy with dumb money flooding the market. Maybe it's just what it should be.

*5g may not be as revolutionary as Qualcomm and radio vendors want it to be. It has its own technical challenges that must be overcome for some of the great benefits to be realized so those features can be enabled. How that rolls out is work in progress.

*Longer term I would be looking at the satalite radio communications/internet as possible disruptors.

author: TheBullishPanda
body:
Renewable Energy (excluding nuclear)

As stated before me, renewables are more than likely to be the future of energy. The reason I think investing here is safer than any tech or space company is the capital needed to participate and the time it takes to acquire/build wine and solar plants.

As recently seen at Qualcomm and before that on many other occasions, tech stocks as well as crypto are extremely vulnerable to disruption. One malfunction, one competitor with a better code or a single security breach can ruin companies for ever. And competition is only getting steeper with almost anybody with a PC able to try to compete.

Opposed to that, renewable energy is a necessity for long term sustained life in earth. Wind and solar plants are extrmly expensive to build and in most of the world you need a government permit to build them. This narrows down the companies likely to succeed substantially. Furthermore, once a plant is installed and the debt you took on to build it is paid off, it's pretty much free money on a great margin.

So yeah, probably not anymore the fastest growing industry out there, but one with stable cash flows, a good dividend and a great outlook for about as far as we can try to foresee the future.

author: Majesticpork
body:
Qualcomm biggest strength is it's hold on crucial patterns in chip technologies. Even AMD has to release their Epyc line of chips quickly before Qualcomm cashes in on their growth with a new contract on the cores number.

So the block before Qualcomm is whether it can retain the hold on the patterns or will the other big tech manage to create something on their own and bypass Qualcomm?

Both Google and Apple are trying obviously. However Qualcomm hold is quite extensive. They don't just hold patterns on the chips but also the architectures as well as the implementation.

Microsoft and AMD are also teaming up to fight back.

Nvidia is trying to push it's AI friendly chip into various markets. If they succeed then Qualcomm will loose big because Nvidia will offer their stuff for cheap to grab market share.

Intel is losing to everyone but I have no doubt they will try to invent something before they completely lose.

author: jwonz_
body:
Yes, “model”, as in modeling based on a previous hype bubble to estimate how long until people sell an over valued position.

Did you know you can read comment threads from 1999 on QCOM and see people calculating a PE of 300 and justifying it? It’s quite hilarious.

You’re right that I should do a proper valuation model on TSLA given growth and margin assumptions. Last time I played with one of these a price of 700 required great margins and 100% growth of car sales up to the same amount as Toyota. I don’t see how they achieve the margins.

Guess I need to google these guys, second time they are mentioned.

author: JayArlington
body:
I think the closest thing to a bear case for QCOM is that they get nailed via some antitrust case over their existing policy of “no license no chip”.   

This is where you don’t get their best chips unless you also license their technology (fat margins).  

QCOM is up there with NVDA in being hated by their customers but that’s the price for being VERY good.

author: 2CommaNoob
body:
The only hold forever is the index ETFs or mutual funds.  Good companies have long lure periods of no stock movement.  Apple, MSFT, IBM, Intel, Qcom, F, GM, Xom, Cisco etc all have years long periods where the stock did absolutely nothing or even lost money.

Unless you got into KO/JPM/BAC/Xom in the 70s; you are underperforming the general market.  It doesn't mean you can't hold individual stocks; you can do both.  Hold some ETFs and trade some stocks that you like.

author: uhhsam
body:
My personal for-fun portfolio that has been mostly cleaned up after a rocky reddit-fueled start (retirement fund is all fine and boring and chugging along boringly somewhere (I hope)):


VUG - 18%

VYM - 16%

TXN - 11%

QCOM - 9%

YUM - 8%

HD - 7%

TGT - 6%

NVDA - 5%

MSOS - 4%

TTNDY - 4%

ASO - 3%

WSM - 3%

SLV - 3%

HOL - 1%

MJ - 1%

LB - 1%


Notes: I got drawn in by the Gamestop hype.  Luckily, I had a moment of doubt and cancelled the orders I had placed during the weekend it had peaked.  I still ended up starting off pretty semiconductor-heavy and have slowly been working at decreasing their overall share of my portfolio, although I feel I am falling into a pit of consumer discretionary stocks.

The ones I'm still slightly ashamed of are HOL, SLV, and the two cannabis ETFs (MSOS and MJ).  I'm in no rush to get rid of them, though.

I would also love to put more into LB, but I'd like to wait to see how the separation plays out so I don't end up with half of the money I put in getting converted to Victoria's Secret stock or something, since I'm only interested in the Bath & Body Works side of the business.

Overall, it may not be ideal, but it's mine and it makes me happy, and I'm to a point where I no longer see red days as being my fault and rather as just what the market did that day.
